FacilityName: Kent County Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy



The Kent County Levy Court has set a safety policy that requires the facility to meet or exceed 

any OSHA standard.  The Kent County Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility (KCRWTF) is 

certified to ISO 14001, and OHSAS 18001.  As a part of this certification, senior KCRWTF 

management is committed to reducing the environmental, health and safety impacts of its 

operations.  A long term goal of the program is to eliminate the use of both gaseous chlorine and 

sulfur dioxide.  The program also establishes a short term goal of protecting the employee and 

public health and safety.  This is accomplished by organizing, equipping and training a select 

team of employees to respond to any incidents involving releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide, 

and to installing monitoring, preventive and mitigation processes to prevent or reduce any 

releases.



Kent County Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility and the regulated substances 

handled.



The KCRWTF is a secondary wastewater treatment facility that handles the majority of 

wastewater generated within Kent County and some wastewater from areas in New Castle and 

Sussex Counties that border Kent County.  The facility uses fine bubble aeration to initially treat 

the wastewater followed by clarification.  The treated wastewater is then chlorinated to reduce 

pathogens and dechlorinated to remove residual chlorine.  The regulated substances that are 

handled on site are gaseous chlorine stored in up to eight (8) one-ton cylinders as a liquid under 

pressure and sulfur dioxide stored in up to 6 (6) one-ton cylinders as a liquid under pressure.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program



The KCRWTF has established detailed procedure for both the chlorine and sulfur dioxide 

systems.  There are alarms and other engineering controls on both systems to prevent releases of 

the regulated substances.  Additional monitoring systems have been a

dded to the operations.  

Operators inspect both systems once every two hours looking for leaks and ensuring that they are 

both operating properly.  Detailed standard operating procedures (SOP?s) that meet the ISO 1001 

and OHSAS 18001 requirements have been implemented and all operators are trained on these 

SOP?s.   Additional training has been provided to operators and local responders.  The operators 

have been trained on how the control systems operate, what constitutes an emergency and how to 

respond to any emergency.  Local responders have been trained on the expected hazards and how 

the control systems operate.  The facility?s SCADA system monitors the system operations and 

alarms when unusual conditions occur.  The SCADA system is monitored by plant personnel 24 

hours a day.



Five Year Accident History



There have been no major incidents involving the regulated hazards over the past twenty years.  

A small release of chlorine (less than 100 pounds) occurred on July 31, 2006 which resulted in a 

major review of current SOP?s and operating systems with minor equipment and procedural 

changes occurring as a result.  The release was confined to the immediate area of the system and 

did not pose a risk to the general public.



The Emergency Response Program



In the event of an emergency involving any of the regulated hazards, the local 911 center will be 

called.  A plant response team will be dressed out as required by the hazard and seek to respond 

to the incident and try to correct the problem.  Senior management at the facility will be 

mobilized as the control team.  The local volunteer fire departments will immediately be 

dispatched.  The Delaware Emergency Management Agency (DEMA) will be notified and 

DNREC and other agencies will respond to provide appropriate support.  Kent County will also 

mobilize its emergency response unit.  The response team is currently under going retraining, 

additional personal protective equ

ipment have been ordered and a table top exercise involving 

the team is expected to be to conducted shortly with a full response exercise scheduled for Spring 

2007.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The KCRWTF will under its Environmental Health and Safety Management System (EHS-MS), 

seek to find alternatives to the use of pure chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  The facility will evaluate 

the use of ultraviolet (UV) disinfection and intends to use it for an expansion.  The facility will 

also seek to replace the chlorine with either liquid sodium hydroxide or solid calcium chloride.
